topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545d89be636872761f7a0100#post_545d89be636872761f7a0100
if you think resources need to be distributed. 
The poor today are not better off than they were a century ago because of welfare. Quite the opposite in fact since welfare is need based so it subsidizes bad behavior (like the dissolution of family one sees among the underclass which makes it harder to move up from poverty).
The poor are better off because the market has improved technology and productivity.
topics.author: 4fe16df67f123b13e400003f

topics.body:
"@Meresflut":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545d89dc636872723f7f0200#post_545d89dc636872723f7f0200

They touch on different matters but seeing back to back allows you to compare different grasps on the extremes in the class system. You see the emotional and moral priorities of both a high class citizen and a worker who could be seen as victim of the former.

I like you already

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545d8a956368723459900100#post_545d8a956368723459900100
Thats also what an international approach gives us. One is set in the victorian England, the other in the middle of the mountains of Mexico. The most exquisite difference is in the way of the characters to perceive life according to their cultures. It lets you see how the two of these see life according to their cultural past. 
I like you too pal, I certainly do.

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/545d8b2b63687202990d0100#post_545d8b2b63687202990d0100

If it's about the incentive, it has to be directed to investors and giving them a guarantee that their money will be worth at the end of that day.

That kind of circulation, at least theoretically, can work in a mass net, but really when you think of it, most of this systems are meant for small states that can be easily managed, and even more important, that it can go in accordance to other systems that will interact with you out of necessity.
